body: TRAVELING in the South of France in recent weeks, João Correia, a former Manhattan publishing executive who shed 60 pounds in recent years, found temptation everywhere: oven-fresh baguettes dabbed in oozy Camembert, sugary tartes Tatin. A morning pain au chocolat, washed down with a rich café au lait? Off limits. ''Oatmeal and black coffee is the
title: Back in Racing Form After Dropping the Fork

body: Norval C. White, a co-author of the authoritative, encyclopedic, opinionated and constantly consulted AIA Guide to New York City, died Saturday at his home in the village of Roques, in southwest France. He was 83. The cause was a heart attack, said his wife, Camilla Crowe White. First published in 1968, the AIA Guide tapped into and fostered a
title: Norval White, of AIA Guide, Dies at 83

body: The unemployment rate for New York City has risen to 10 percent and above in recent months, but a new study shows that joblessness ranges from nearly twice that figure in some neighborhoods to only half as much in others. The situation is worst in the East New York section of Brooklyn, where the unemployment rate for the third quarter of this year
title: Study Shows Jobless Rate Varies Widely Across City

body: There were days upon days in New York City when not a single person was murdered in 2009. Two such stretches, in February and March, lasted nearly a week each. There were some pockets of the city where homicide was a singular occurrence: 12 of the city's 77 police precincts, in locations as varied as Hamilton Heights, in Upper Manhattan, and Park
title: HOMICIDES NEAR RECORD LOW RATE IN NEW YORK CITY

body: It's that time when people begin dutifully dusting off those cherished Christmas stories, the ones they can't get enough of. The plots never change. Same outcome every time for Scrooge and Rudolph and Charlie Brown. Then there are the true stories that still breathe, susceptible to the fickle whims and winds of life. They twist their way to fresh
title: Their Christmas Tale, With a New Chapter

After bouncing around among apartments in Brooklyn, Manhattan, Chicago and Los Angeles, Ms. Bodner had finally alighted in a place she loved. And determined not to be one of
title: HABITATS; Post-Industrial Order

title: Musical Tidings of Comfort, Joy and Jubilation

body: HULBERT--Dorothy Hanni, on December 4, 2009, of lung cancer. She was born December 21, 1928, in Sidney, New York, to Swiss immigrant parents. title: Paid Notice: Deaths HULBERT, DOROTHY HANNI

title: Metropolitan Diary

title: Don Congdon, Longtime Literary Agent for Ray Bradbury, Dies at 91

body: My older son, Gabe, turned 3 in May, and I knew this would be the season I would finally take him to his first basketball game. I wanted the experience to be fun, the start of what I hoped would be a lifetime of basketball fandom. In part, it is his family legacy. My wife, Margery, and I love the game. As for social currency, fluency in fandom will
title: Family Matters

title: Theodore Roosevelt IV Opts Out of G.O.P. Race for Senate

body: More than 11,000 people received swine flu vaccines at free clinics last weekend, city officials said, while overall infection rates remained relatively low. The Department of Health and Mental Hygiene has ordered more than a million doses of the vaccine. Most of them are going to in-school vaccinations, weekend clinics, hospitals and private
title: Swine Flu Vaccinations Rise While Infections Remain Low

body: NEW YORKERS get to feel smug about a lot of things. We have great food, arts and culture, the Yankees. We can also feel good about our relatively low use of energy, thanks to public transportation and our small living spaces. But sometimes -- sometimes -- we fail to notice where there's room for improvement. Thirty-nine percent of New York City's
title: Start Small and Think Long-Term: Saving Energy

body: Once Andrea Combs sensed that layoffs were imminent, she went to her caseworker's office with a sense of purpose. ''She said she wanted to revise her résumé, so we went back and forth and revised it, so she was prepared even before she got laid off,'' recalled Mimi Watanabe, her caseworker at the Brooklyn Bureau of Community Service. title: After Other Hardships, Trying to Bounce Back From Unemployment

title: Bidding Wars Resume

Then the recession thundered in, and suddenly young men found themselves one of the hardest
title: The Decline and Fall Of the Bachelor Pad

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's campaign, having spent $100 million or more on ads and outreach, would love to be able to buy a 60-degree day. The higher the temperature, the thinking goes among Mr. Bloomberg's staff, the wider the margin of victory. William C. Thompson Jr.'s campaign is more interested in the city's emotional temperature -- hoping
title: Mayoral Campaigns Look Skyward, and Everywhere Else, for the Keys to Victory

body: HELEN PEARLSTEIN, an ebullient blonde in her 60s, may not be the single best-known resident of Concord Village, the Brooklyn co-op where she has lived for nearly a quarter of a century. But she is probably near the top of the list. A member of her co-op board for six years and the president for nearly two, Ms. Pearlstein is deeply involved with
title: HABITATS; A Makeover As Homage To the Past

body: HENRY ELGHANAYAN marched into a conference room high above Third Avenue in Midtown Manhattan on March 4. After nearly four decades as partners, he and two of his brothers were dividing up their $3 billion real estate empire. As if it were some neighborhood bet, the flip of a coin would determine how to split their 8,000 apartments and nine
title: Flipping a Coin, Dividing an Empire

body: Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's announcement last October that he would seek a third term could not have come at a worse time for City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. And it was not just his political fate that concerned him. Mr. Thompson also had a young marriage to think about. His wife, Elsie McCabe Thompson, had been left alone to raise twin
title: From the Sidelines, Supporting Her Husband's Quest to Be Mayor

title: ROOMS; Interior Shots: Where You Wanted to Go

body: BIG cities like New York are both deeply convenient -- two steps to the deli for milk in the morning -- and deeply inconvenient. It is possible to live in the same city as the person you are dating, and have to travel an hour, or even two, to get together. Those long subway rides are so annoying that they shape not only dating patterns, but real
title: When Love Is a Schlep

title: Jody Mullen, Gary Oeters

body: Through the building frenzy that transformed some of the city's long-neglected patches into lustrous new neighborhoods, few frontiers struggled to reap the benefits of gentrification more than working-class Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Prices of homes rose, but never as much as in Fort Greene. Its long-neglected brownstones attracted renovators
title: Amid a Citywide Slump, a Local Exception

body: At the age of 37, with a loaded résumé and a reputation as a serious thinker, David Yassky arrived at the City Council and was quickly handed his first defeat. He was part of a group that failed to persuade city officials to push developers to include apartments for low- and moderate-income renters as part of a rezoning in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
title: Known for His Pragmatic Approach

body: The mandala logos appear every few blocks or so, each heralding another establishment tucked into a brownstone storefront, all bearing the generic name Area. Over here, it is a day spa. title: Brooklyn's Tide of Chains, Decidedly Local

body: THE first anniversary last week of the Lehman Brothers collapse was a grim milestone. During the financial meltdown that followed, markets across the globe were roiled. title: The Look Of Autumn

title: 400 Years Later, and Still Proud of New Amsterdam

title: Metropolitan Diary

body: ONE recent afternoon, the writer Amy Sohn sat at the Third Street Playground in Prospect Park, Brooklyn, a few blocks from her apartment, and explained the central paradox of her neighborhood. title: AT HOME WITH AMY SOHN; A Park Slope Novel Seems a Little Too Real

body: The fierce tug of war between New York and New Jersey over 2,300 financial jobs in Lower Manhattan is just about over. title: New Jersey Wins 1,600 Financial Jobs

body: ROB a bank, and if the federal government doesn't catch you in five years, you're off the hook. The stylist, Robert Nocco, found out that his landlord could legally
title: BIG DEAL; Tenant Loses Rent-Control Battle

body: DMC USA D.J. FINALS Beck and Kanye West are musicians who on the surface have little in common. Beck is a subgenre-hopping rock musician who first gained notice with the depression-inducing song ''Loser,'' while Kanye West's real-life chest-thumping boasts are almost as memorable as those in his rhymes. But when looking for accompaniment to their
title: Spare Times

body: WHEN John Patrick Shanley gave a book party for his friend Allegra Huston earlier this year, guests stayed at his Gramercy Park apartment well into the night. The playwright, director and Oscar-winning screenwriter attributed the success of the party partly to the color of his living room. ''I find that green is comforting to people,'' he said.
title: ON LOCATION; The Color of Comfort

body: VALISA AND JAMES TATE were among the first residents to move into One Brooklyn Bridge Park, a condominium project in Brooklyn Heights, in the summer of 2008. A year later, the hallways still feel barren. Only 77 of the building's 438 apartments have closed. Twenty-six are in contract. In order to keep money coming in during a difficult time for
title: Renters to the Rescue

body: For years, top Manhattan public schools have raised hundreds of thousands of dollars from parents to independently hire assistants to help teachers with reading, writing, tying shoelaces or supervising recess. But after a complaint by the city's powerful teachers union, the Bloomberg administration has ordered an end to the makeshift practice.
title: Parent-Paid Aides Ordered Out of City Schools

title: Gotta Move, Gotta Sell

body: BABIES AT THE Y, And Fathers Too The classes were originally called ''Mommy and Baby.'' Then men started showing up one by one, infants in tow. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

title: The Future Is Theirs

body: ROCKSTOCK & BARRELS New York is known more for its asphalt than its sandy shores, so you can be forgiven for ignoring the 14 miles of public beaches within the five boroughs. title: SPARE TIMES

author: Emily Bazelon, a contributing writer, is a founding editor of Double X, Slate's new Web site for women, and is the Truman Capote fellow at Yale Law School.
body: On a rainy morning in April, Lisa Feuer took the subway to the Brooklyn Dojo, a martial-arts studio where she was scheduled to teach a mommy-baby yoga class. Outside, streams of water poured from awnings into the collars of passers-by. When she got to the studio, Feuer shook out her umbrella and picked out music from her iPhone to play for the
title: What happened to all those liberated, self-reliant, self-branded free agents?

body: THE hookahs looked like exotic animals lurking in Hookahnuts, a shop for gifts and food in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. In various shades of red, blue and green, these water pipes, used to smoke flavored tobacco, were the most vivid sign of the shop's Middle Eastern culture, presented among an eye-catching array that included intricate wooden trays,
title: Festival for New York, That Muslim City

body: THE TOM TOM CREW If you know your Shakespeare, it's easy to feel leery of a show created by an outfit called Strut & Fret Production House. The name of course evokes Macbeth's bitter soliloquy in which he compares life to ''a poor player,/That struts and frets his hour upon the stage,/And then is heard no more.'' While the Tom Tom Crew indeed
title: Spare Times | For Children

body: Thank the Hens Egg rolls from Chinatown and egg creams from the Lower East Side will be celebrated and served ($4 for both) at a June 7 street fair from noon to 4 p.m. at the Eldridge Street Synagogue, 12 Eldridge Street (Canal Street). title: Calendar

body: THE old-fashioned may finally be earning its name. One of the most venerable of whiskey-based cocktails, it has a history that stretches back farther than the martini's. For decades it has suffered under the reputation of something your grandmother drank -- overly sweet, fruit-laden and spritzed-up. But grandma wouldn't recognize what's happened to
title: Take a Sip Of History

body: Quantity and Quality Eight contestants will see who can eat the most Texas-style pork ribs in 10 minutes at Hill Country, 30 West 26th Street, on June 6 at 2 p.m. A $5 admission fee and a matching donation from the restaurant will go to the Madison Square Park Conservancy. title: Benefits

body: THE tedious 35-minute subway ride between David Basner's studio in Chelsea and Courtney Reimer's one-bedroom in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn, annoyed both of them. Each disliked the other's place, too. She felt that his -- so small it fit only a twin bed -- was cramped and dark. He felt that hers was inconvenient and impractical. Except for maybe a
title: THE HUNT; A Place They Both Call Home

body: As Robert Lopez tells it, his trouble began nearly two years ago when he plucked a bundle of fake dynamite from the trash in Brooklyn and took it home with plans to turn it into a piggy bank. Now Mr. Lopez, 38, a career maintenance man with no criminal record beyond a 10-year-old marijuana possession violation, is set to appear in court on Thursday
title: Trashy Treasure Leads to Felony False-Bomb Charge

body: FOR $1,000 a month, most New Yorkers expect to rent little more than a tiny cramped space devoid of light and charm. title: Not a Dive After All

body: WHERE THE METERS Don't Get Cold We'd heard of tea cozies. But now Brooklyn Heights has introduced parking-meter cozies -- 69 of them, in fact. title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: BECAUSE Peter Aaron's box-shaped 1858 Italianate house here is as deep as it is wide, square-footage calculation ought to be easy. ''It's whatever it is across -- 33 feet -- squared, and then it's twice that, because the second story has the same measurements as the first,'' Mr. Aaron said the other day. ''Except for the kitchen, which was added on
title: ON LOCATION; A Portraitist Of Homes Remakes His Own

body: A college sophomore who worked as a nanny and baby sitter for more than 20 families in and around New York City has been charged with sexually abusing three boys from Manhattan, officials said on Friday. The man, Jonathan Then, 21, a student at Hunter College, was ordered held without bail after his arraignment in Manhattan Criminal Court on Friday
title: Baby Sitter Is Charged With Sexual Abuse of 3 Boys

title: Made in Brooklyn

body: FOR months, Michelle Cianfaglione felt as if she did nothing but look for an apartment. ''It was fun for a while,'' she said, ''but it consumed hours and hours.'' Night after night, she would find herself sitting at the computer thinking, ''All I did was search for apartments all evening, and I still haven't found one!'' Open houses in Manhattan
title: THE HUNT; The 10 Percent Hurdle

body: THE season of house tours, garden tours and show houses is here, when visitors are invited into skinny row houses, sprawling apartments and vast estates to study their gleaming kitchens, burnished woodwork, antiques and artworks and city or country views. title: URBAN STUDIES | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The Ghost Ships of the Hudson

title: ...Beyond Their Fathers' Musical Landscapes

title: Paid Notice: Deaths LUTTINGER, DR

body: THERE are few things that New Yorkers react to more quickly than the trilling of a smartphone as it signals the arrival of an e-mail message. With lightning speed they respond to e-mail messages on the street, in cabs, on buses, standing in line at Starbucks, the instant their Q train emerges from darkness onto the Manhattan Bridge. title: The E-Mail Handshake

body: IN 1885, when Brooklyn was still an independent city, the St. George Hotel was rising on Clark Street, just steps from the East River. At 2,623 rooms, it would become the nation's largest and grandest hotel. By the early 1930s, its new tower rose more than 30 stories. Occupying an entire block of Brooklyn Heights, between Hicks, Henry, Clark and
title: BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; Trying to Recapture the Glory Days, Up in the Old Hotel

title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; How Mr. Toast Took a Bath

body: James Purdy, whose dark, often savagely comic fiction evoked an American psychic landscape of deluded innocence, sexual obsession, violence and isolation, died on Friday in Englewood, N.J. title: James Purdy, a Literary Outsider With a Piercing Vision, Is Dead at 94

title: LIVING IN | FORT GREENE, BROOKLYN; Multiple Identities Can Be a Good Thing

title: WINE UNDER $20; Smoothly Does It

title: HABITATS | BROOKLYN HEIGHTS; The Sofa That Ate Brooklyn

body: IN 1936, Literary Digest reported that New York was dazzled by neon signs, with 300 in Times Square alone, some larger than a boxcar. Now, in the same area, the occasional spot of neon is like a cork bobbing on a sea of big LED and back-lit plastic signs. But a score or more of distinctive smaller signs from earlier times shine on, although their
title: STREETSCAPES | NEON SIGNS; The Best And the Brightest

title: Four Buildings Clear Big Step Toward Landmark Status

title: NEW YORK OBSERVED; The Tunnel Rats of Atlantic Avenue

body: IN this painful economic climate of layoffs and shrinking investments, there is a sliver of positive news: it's a good time to be a renter in New York City. title: A Month Free? Rents Are Falling Fast

body: John Updike defined ''the true New Yorker'' as someone who came with a ''secret belief that people living anywhere else had to be, in some sense, kidding.'' The guy nailed it. In the depths of their souls, that is exactly how unreconstructed New Yorkers feel. Mr. Updike, who died this week at age 76, was definitely not a true New Yorker, even if he
title: NYC; Thoughts on the City By a New Yorker Writer Who Avoided New York

title: Wondering if a New School in Brooklyn Is Worth Blocking a View of the Bridge

title: CITY ROOM BLOGGING AT NYTIMES.COM/CITYROOM.

body: Three generations of Thompsons gathered around the patriarch's dining room table in Brooklyn Heights the other day and gave three varied perspectives on the inauguration of Barack Obama. This prominent black political family from Brooklyn is headed by Harlem-born William C. Thompson. Known as Willie, he is 84 and served in a segregated infantry
title: A Historic Moment, Through One Prominent Brooklyn Family's Perspective

body: AROUND TOWN Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN Staten Island Historical Society. body: FOR more than three months, Tanya Tribble lived in what she called ''the bubble.'' It was the summer of 2007, and Ms. Tribble, a wedding photographer, had decided to stay in her loft, a 950-square-foot co-op on Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, despite the dust and clamor of a gut renovation. title: THE SELL; A Deal Squared by a Round Number

body: THREE KINGS DAY The lights have been taken down, the trees are on the way to the mulch pile, and Christmas cards are being offered at staggering discounts, but holiday celebrations aren't over yet. body: In the 17 years ''The Real World'' has been appearing on MTV, it has deployed the services of 400 editors to scan 40,000 hours of film. title: TELEVISION REVIEW | 'THE REAL WORLD'; The Show That Put the 'Real' in Reality TV

body: ''I'M really a modernist,'' said Serine Hastings, who lived in prewar apartments her first three decades in New York. Since moving from Chicago in the late 1970s, she has always made her home in places with vintage architectural details. ''I lived on the top floor of a Federal town house in Chelsea and a co-op on the Upper West Side,'' said Ms.
title: HABITATS | BOERUM HILL, BROOKLYN; After All Those Brownstones, a Blank Canvas

body: '50 FIRST JOKES' Eating black-eyed peas, being hung over, regrets -- everyone has a New Year's tradition. For the show ''50 First Jokes'' on Saturday, 50 comedians will start 2009 with a new punch line.
